010package imagingbook.common.noise.hashing;
011
012/**
013 * <p>
014 * Permutation-based hash function, similar to the one proposed in [1]. See [2]
015 * for details.
016 * </p>
017 * <p>
018 * [1] K. Perlin. An image synthesizer. SIGGRAPH Computer Graphics 19(3),
019 * 287â€“296 (1985). <br>
020 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Principles of Digital Image Processing &ndash;
021 * Advanced Methods</em> (Vol. 3), Supplementary Chapter 8: "Synthetic Gradient
022 * Noise", Springer (2013).
023 * </p>
024 * 
025 * @author WB
026 * @version 2022/11/24
027 */
028public class HashPermute implements HashFunction {
029        
030        private final int seed;
031        
032        /**
033         * Constructor, creates a hash function with a random seed value.
034         */
035        HashPermute() {
036                this(0);
037        }
038        
039        /**
040         * Constructor creating a hash function with the specified seed value.
041         * @param seed the random seed value (set to 0 use a random seed value).
042         */
043        public HashPermute(int seed) {
044                this.seed = HashFunction.getRandomSeed(seed);
045        }
046        
047        @Override
048        public double hash(int u) {
049                int h = h8(u);
050                return (double) (h & 0xFF) / 0xFF; // use bits 0..7 for d
051        }
052        
053        // 6 bits per channel (overlapping blocks)
054        @Override
055        public double[] hash(int u, int v) {
056                final int M = 0x3F; // 63;
057                int h = h8(u, v);
058                double hx = h & M;                      // use bits 0..5 for dx
059                double hy = (h >> 2) & M;       // use bits 2..7 for dy
060                return new double[] {hx/M, hy/M};
061        }
062        
063        @Override
064        public double[] hash(int u, int v, int w) {
065                final int M = 0x0F;
066                int h = h8(u, v, w);
067                double hx =  h & M;                     // use bits 0..3 for x
068                double hy = ((h >> 2) & M);     // use bits 2..5 for y
069                double hz = ((h >> 4) & M);     // use bits 4..7 for z
070                return new double[] {hx/M, hy/M, hz/M};
071        }
072
073        // 2 dimensions
074        private int h8 (int u) {
075                u = (u + seed) & 0xFF;
076                return P[u];
077        }
078        
079        // 2 dimensions
080        private int h8 (int u, int v) {
081                u = (u + seed) & 0xFF;
082                v = v & 0xFF;
083                return P[P[v] + u];
084        }
085        
086        // 3 dimensions
087        private int h8 (int u, int v, int w) {
088                u = (u + seed) & 0xFF;
089                v = v & 0xFF;
090                w = w & 0xFF;
091                return P[P[P[w] + v] + u];
092        }
093        
094        @Override
095        /*
096         * N-dimensional permutation hash; this version does not use
097         * any bit splitting. Instead, the hash8() function is
098         * applied repeatedly for every gradient dimension by 
099         * using the dimension number (k) as a local seed (sd) - 
100         * in addition to the global seed (seed).
101         */
102        public double[] hash(int[] p) {
103                int N = p.length;
104                double[] g = new double[N];
105                for (int k = 0; k < N; k++) {           // dimension k
106                        int h = h8(p, k + seed);
107                        g[k] = (double) (h & 0xFF) / 0xFF;
108                }
109                return g;
110        }
111        
112        /*
113         * N-dimensional permutation hash function
114         */
115        private int h8 (int[] p, int sd) {
116                int h = sd & 0xFF;
117                for (int k = 0; k < p.length; k++) {
118                        h = P[h + p[k] & 0xFF];
119                }
120                return h;
121        }
122
123        /*
124         * Permutation table P[i], for i = 0..255. To avoid index wrapping, 
125         * table's length is doubled to 512.
126         */
127        static final int P[] = new int[512];
128        static {
129                int[] perm = {
130                                151, 160, 137, 91, 90, 15, 131, 13, 
131                                201, 95, 96, 53, 194, 233, 7, 225, 
132                                140, 36, 103, 30, 69, 142, 8, 99, 
133                                37, 240, 21, 10, 23, 190, 6, 148, 
134                                247, 120, 234, 75, 0, 26, 197, 62,
135                                94,     252, 219, 203, 117, 35, 11, 32, 
136                                57, 177, 33, 88, 237, 149, 56, 87, 
137                                174, 20, 125, 136, 171, 168, 68, 175, 
138                                74, 165, 71, 134, 139, 48, 27, 166, 
139                                77, 146, 158, 231, 83, 111, 229, 122, 
140                                60, 211, 133, 230, 220, 105, 92, 41, 
141                                55, 46, 245, 40, 244, 102, 143, 54, 
142                                65, 25, 63, 161, 1, 216, 80, 73, 
143                                209, 76, 132, 187, 208, 89, 18, 169, 
144                                200, 196, 135, 130, 116, 188, 159, 86, 
145                                164, 100, 109, 198, 173, 186, 3, 64,
146                                52, 217, 226, 250, 124, 123, 5, 202, 
147                                38, 147, 118, 126, 255, 82, 85, 212, 
148                                207, 206, 59, 227, 47, 16, 58, 17, 
149                                182, 189, 28, 42, 223, 183, 170, 213, 
150                                119, 248, 152, 2, 44, 154, 163, 70, 
151                                221, 153, 101, 155, 167, 43, 172, 9,
152                                129, 22, 39, 253, 19, 98, 108, 110, 
153                                79, 113, 224, 232, 178, 185, 112, 104,
154                                218, 246, 97, 228, 251, 34, 242, 193, 
155                                238, 210, 144, 12, 191, 179, 162, 241, 
156                                81, 51, 145, 235, 249, 14, 239, 107, 
157                                49, 192, 214, 31, 181, 199, 106, 157, 
158                                184, 84, 204, 176, 115, 121, 50, 45, 
159                                127, 4, 150, 254, 138, 236, 205, 93, 
160                                222, 114, 67, 29, 24, 72, 243, 141, 
161                                128, 195, 78, 66, 215, 61, 156, 180 };
162                for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++)
163                        P[256 + i] = P[i] = perm[i];
164        }
165        
166//      public static void main(String[] args) {
167//              HashPermute hf = new HashPermute();
168//              for (int k = 0; k < 256; k++) {
169//                      System.out.format("%d : %10f\n", k, hf.hash(k));
170//                      
171//              }
172//      }
173}
